header_summary:
Niklas Goegge's announcement reveals critical security vulnerabilities in versions of Bitcoin Core prior to 25.0, alongside introducing a new vulnerability disclosure policy. These vulnerabilities, detailed at [Bitcoin Core's official site](https://bitcoincore.org/en/2024/10/08/disclose-mutated-blocks-hindering-propagation/), [here](https://bitcoincore.org/en/2024/10/08/disclose-large-inv-to-send/), and [here](https://bitcoincore.org/en/2024/10/08/disclose-blocktxn-crash/), address issues ranging from mutated block propagation hindrance to crashes during block transaction processing. The proactive disclosure, including a forthcoming notice on vulnerabilities affecting versions before 26.0, underscores the project's commitment to transparency and security enhancement.

AdamISZ/waxwing's blog post at [Reyify](https://reyify.com/blog/adaptors-generalised/) explores the potential of adaptor signatures to extend beyond current limitations, particularly in the realm of Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKP) and on-chain verification. The discussion, focusing on the theoretical and practical applications of adaptor signatures, indicates a significant step towards broadening the cryptographic protocol's understanding and utility. Waxwing's intent to merge generalized sigma protocols with adaptor signatures could revolutionize their application, despite existing implementation challenges.

Bitcoin Inquisition 28.0 introduces substantial enhancements over Bitcoin Core 28.0, incorporating support for TRUC and anchor relay mechanisms, default full replace by fee behavior, and proposed consensus changes to improve protocol flexibility and security. Detailed at [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin-inquisition/bitcoin/releases/tag/v28.0-inq), these updates signal an evolution in Bitcoin's development, aiming for heightened user experience and network integrity. The release emphasizes the necessity for users desiring their transactions to be mined to connect with inquisition nodes, thereby ensuring the advanced functionalities are fully utilized.

MishaKomarov introduces Bitcoin PIPEs as an innovative approach to implementing covenants on Bitcoin without the need for a soft fork, presenting a significant leap in enabling complex spending conditions and new use cases for Bitcoin. Through the use of Polynomial Inner Product Encryption, Bitcoin PIPEs facilitate the emulation of missing opcodes and the efficient execution of batch transactions and scalable cryptographic proofs. This advancement, detailed at [DelvingBitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bitcoin-pipes-introducting-covenants-without-soft-forks/1183), represents a pivotal moment in Bitcoin’s development, offering enhanced security, privacy, and functionality without compromising the network's foundational principles.

recent_posts.title: Public disclosure of three vulnerabilities affecting Bitcoin Core <v25.0
recent_posts.summary:
- Recent communication reveals security flaws in Bitcoin Core versions before 25.0.
- A new policy aims to boost transparency and security in Bitcoin Core community.
- Future updates will disclose vulnerabilities prior to version 26.0, enhancing protection.

recent_posts.title: Adaptor generalisation
recent_posts.summary:
- AdamISZ explores expanding adaptor signatures beyond traditional uses in cryptography.
- The blog proposes a protocol enabling verification of Discrete Logarithm Equality via adaptor signatures.
- It discusses theoretical and practical applications, including integration with generalized sigma protocols.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Inquisition 28.0
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Inquisition 28.0 introduces TRUC, anchor relay, and full replace by fee features.
- It integrates BIP 119, BIP 118's SIGHASH_ANYPREVOUT, and BIP 347's OP_CAT for improved security.
- Transactions using new features need inquisition node connectivity, ensuring advanced functionality and network integrity.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin PIPEs: Introducting Covenants without Soft Forks
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin PIPEs introduce covenants to Bitcoin, enabling advanced spending rules without a soft fork.
- PIPEs allow complex transactions and Zero-Knowledge Proof verification by emulating opcodes.
- This innovation maintains Bitcoin's security while significantly enhancing its functionality and flexibility.

recent_posts.title: Support for graphing data
recent_posts.summary:
- The integration of Plotly.js in a Discourse theme enhances data visualization in forums.
- Users can interact with dynamic plots, including feerate diagrams and log graphs.
- Plotly's capabilities extend to complex visuals like mapping great circles on a world map.

active_posts.title: Demonstrating Pinning Attacks under Real-World Conditions
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine Riard proposes setting up "free-to-pwn" lightning nodes to test attack techniques.
- The initiative encourages realistic testing on the mainnet to highlight security vulnerabilities.
- Riard critiques certain experts' misleading assurances on protocol safety and economic viability.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.0 Released
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 28.0 introduces new features, bug fixes, and performance improvements.
- Significant updates include Testnet4/BIP94 support, mempool policy improvements, and wallet functionality enhancements.
- The release is compatible with major operating systems and emphasizes security, efficiency, and usability.

active_posts.title: Pure Swift Bitcoin Protocol implementation (largely experimental)
active_posts.summary:
- Swift Bitcoin, hosted on GitHub, focuses on the detailed workings of Bitcoin.
- It features Swift APIs for cryptography, transaction services, and planned P2P communications.
- Open for contributions, it emphasizes protocol development and broad platform compatibility.

active_posts.title: SuperScalar: Laddered Timeout-Tree-Structured Decker-Wattenhofer Factories
active_posts.summary:
- The SuperScalar mechanism enhances Bitcoin Lightning Network's liquidity without needing blockchain changes.
- It incorporates Decker-Wattenhofer mechanisms, timeout trees, and laddering strategies for scalability and security.
- Practical implementation requires incentivizing user activity and strategic tree structuring for efficiency and cost-effectiveness.

active_posts.title: Unspendable keys in descriptors
active_posts.summary:
- Miniscript and taproot integration in Bitcoin Core enhances wallet development options.
- Generating unspendable keys with specific properties for taproot is complex yet vital.
- Among solutions, using a root xpub with a random chaincode is most practical for hardware signers.

active_posts.title: Non-disclosure of a consensus bug in btcd
active_posts.summary:
- In March 2024, a consensus bug in btcd was found and fixed in version 0.24.2.
- The authors and maintainers debated the public disclosure timing, emphasizing transparency.
- Despite a minor network impact, upgrading to btcd v0.24.2 is critical for security.

today_in_history_posts.title: Transaction Input/Output Sorting
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Wallets' transaction sorting methods allow for easy identification between them.
- Some wallets resist deterministic sorting due to privacy concerns and future compatibility.
- The proposed solution uses a semi-secret for deterministic but seemingly random sorting.

today_in_history_posts.title: RFC: simplifications and suggestions on open/accept limits.
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Gert-Jaap Glasbergen advises against removing htlc_minimum_msat for protection against trimmed HTLCs.
- He proposes varying "dust" definitions with fees and setting minimum_depth per chain.
- Rusty agrees on chain-dependent minimum_depth but views opting out below 1000 msat impractical.

today_in_history_posts.title: Project categories?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The discussion proposes categories for bitcoin projects on platforms like GitHub.
- It suggests a dedicated space for centralized announcements and discussions.
- The approach offers moderation capabilities and enhances information organization.
